Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in GROW (Graduate Research Opportunities for Women) 2019, held October 4-6, 2019 at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. This is a conference focused on female undergraduate students who wish to pursue graduate studies in the mathematical sciences. The conference addresses the crucial transition from undergraduate to graduate school, at which the percentage of women drops significantly. It aims to directly increase the proportion and the absolute number of female US students in graduate programs in the mathematical sciences.

The conference will feature four hour-long lectures by highly recognized mathematicians on cutting edge research. Collectively, they will cover a broad spectrum of pure and applied mathematics: algebraic combinatorics, epidemiology, homology theory and non-commutative algebra. Informal roundtable discussions at the conclusion of the conference will allow the participants to learn more about research subjects they find interesting, important open problems, current progress and main challenges. Lectures will be accompanied by panel discussions, where the participants will receive information and advice about the application process for graduate school and being a graduate student, and career opportunities in mathematics. More information about the conference can be found at https://math.illinois.edu/grow2019

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
GROW 2019 is part of the “Graduate Research Opportunities for Women” conference series. It took place on October 4-6, 2019 at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. One of the primary goals of the conference was to directly increase the proportion and the absolute number of US women students in the graduate programs in the mathematical sciences, by providing information about graduate school and mentorship to students who may be considering applying to graduate programs. More than 50 external participants attended the conference and were supported through this NSF award. For three days female-identified mathematicians at various academic stages (undergraduate attendants, graduate student organizers, postdoc panelists, tenure-track professors), and several female mathematicians working in the industry participated in a wide range of activities. These included round-table discussions, research talks where cutting-edge mathematics was presented, and sessions where advice on preparing application material for graduate school was provided. During the conference there were ample opportunities for undergraduate participants to network and be exposed to the life of mathematicians. On the more practical side, participants had access to brochures advertising graduate programs at various research universities and received direct guidance and feedback about their application materials both from graduate students and from faculty. The GROW conference series was recognized by the American Mathematical Society with the 2020 “Mathematics Program that Make a Difference” award.
